output_text: आपके प्रश्न का उत्तर देने के लिए, मैं 2022 में Pine, Aidan et al. द्वारा संकलित की गई जानकारी का संदर्भ लूंगी। इस क्रांतिकारी शोध पत्रिका में लेख "Requirements and Motivations of Low-Resource Speech Synthesis for Language Revitalization" में Canadian indigenous communities के बारे में उल्लेख है जो low-to-moderate severity severity linguistic isolation, low literacy rates, और scarce linguistic resources का सामना करते हैं।इसके मुताबिक, Canada में 10,000 से अधिक indigenous भाषाओं का अभाव है। यहाँ, आठ प्रमुख native भाषाओं का उद्देश्यित बहुसंख्या के 50% से अधिक के लिए वांछित समुदाय में बोला जा रहा है, और यहाँ एक हजार से अधिक पहली भाषाओं में साक्षरता दर 2 से 20% के सीमित सीमित है। Keep in mind that this information is as of 2022, and you should verify the figures for current data. Would you like any further clarification or details from the paper?

title: EconAgent: Large Language Model-Empowered Agents for Simulating Macroeconomic Activities
abstract: The advent of artificial intelligence has led to a growing emphasis on data-driven modeling in macroeconomics, with agent-based modeling (ABM) emerging as a prominent bottom-up simulation paradigm. In ABM, agents (*e.g.*, households, firms) interact within a macroeconomic environment, collectively generating market dynamics. Existing agent modeling typically employs predetermined rules or learning-based neural networks for decision-making. However, customizing each agent presents significant challenges, complicating the modeling of agent heterogeneity. Additionally, the influence of multi-period market dynamics and multifaceted macroeconomic factors are often overlooked in decision-making processes.In this work, we introduce **EconAgent**, a large language model-empowered agent with human-like characteristics for macroeconomic simulation. We first construct a simulation environment that incorporates various market dynamics driven by agents’ decisions regarding work and consumption. Through the perception module, we create heterogeneous agents with distinct decision-making mechanisms. Furthermore, we model the impact of macroeconomic trends using a memory module, which allows agents to reflect on past individual experiences and market dynamics.Simulation experiments show that EconAgent can make realistic decisions, leading to more reasonable macroeconomic phenomena compared to existing rule-based or learning-based agents. Our codes are released at https://github.com/tsinghua-fib-lab/ACL24-EconAgent.
question: DSGE का विस्तारित रूप क्या है?
prompt: "EconAgent: Large Language Model-Empowered Agents for Simulating Macroeconomic Activities" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Li,Nian et al. द्वारा, dsGE का विस्तारित रूप क्या है?
output_text: In the paper "EconAgent: Large Language Model-Empowered Agents for Simulating Macroeconomic Activities" by Li, Nian et al., the authors introduce a novel framework for expanding the capabilities of the Dynamic Stochastic General Equilibrium (DSGE) model, which is a common tool used in macroeconomic modeling. They propose a new approach that incorporates large language models (LLMs) into the simulation process.

title: Don’t Blame the Annotator: Bias Already Starts in the Annotation Instructions
abstract: In recent years, progress in NLU has been driven by benchmarks. These benchmarks are typically collected by crowdsourcing, where annotators write examples based on annotation instructions crafted by dataset creators. In this work, we hypothesize that annotators pick up on patterns in the crowdsourcing instructions, which bias them to write many similar examples that are then over-represented in the collected data. We study this form of bias, termed instruction bias, in 14 recent NLU benchmarks, showing that instruction examples often exhibit concrete patterns, which are propagated by crowdworkers to the collected data. This extends previous work (Geva et al., 2019) and raises a new concern of whether we are modeling the dataset creator’s instructions, rather than the task. Through a series of experiments, we show that, indeed, instruction bias can lead to overestimation of model performance, and that models struggle to generalize beyond biases originating in the crowdsourcing instructions. We further analyze the influence of instruction bias in terms of pattern frequency and model size, and derive concrete recommendations for creating future NLU benchmarks.
question: Abstract के अनुसार, instruction bias का अध्ययन कितने NLU benchmarks में किया गया है।
prompt: "Don’t Blame the Annotator: Bias Already Starts in the Annotation Instructions" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Parmar,Mihir et al. द्वारा, abstract के अनुसार, instruction bias का अध्ययन कितने NLU benchmarks में किया गया है।
output_text: The paper "Don't Blame the Annotator: Bias Already Starts in the Annotation Instructions" by Parmar et al. presents the results of their study on instruction bias in various NLU benchmarks. They tested instruction bias in several NLU datasets, including the SNLI dataset for natural language inference, the QNLI dataset for question-answering, and the HANS dataset for text and semantic entailment.Therefore, according to the abstract, instruction bias has been studied in at least three NLU benchmarks, specifically:1. SNLI (Large-Scale Natural Language Inference) dataset2. QNLI (Question-NLI) dataset3. HANS (Hierarchical Commonsense Anchors) dataset

title: Specializing Word Embeddings (for Parsing) by Information Bottleneck
abstract: Pre-trained word embeddings like ELMo and BERT contain rich syntactic and semantic information, resulting in state-of-the-art performance on various tasks. We propose a very fast variational information bottleneck (VIB) method to nonlinearly compress these embeddings, keeping only the information that helps a discriminative parser. We compress each word embedding to either a discrete tag or a continuous vector. In the discrete version, our automatically compressed tags form an alternative tag set: we show experimentally that our tags capture most of the information in traditional POS tag annotations, but our tag sequences can be parsed more accurately at the same level of tag granularity. In the continuous version, we show experimentally that moderately compressing the word embeddings by our method yields a more accurate parser in 8 of 9 languages, unlike simple dimensionality reduction.
question: VIB का विस्तारित रूप क्या है?
prompt: "Specializing Word Embeddings (for Parsing) by Information Bottleneck" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Li,Xiang Lisa et al. द्वारा, viB का विस्तारित रूप क्या है?
output_text: The article "Specializing Word Embeddings (for Parsing) by Information Bottleneck" written by Li, Xiang Lisa et al. introduces the concept of viB, an extension of the Information Bottleneck (IB) theory.In this context, viB stands for "variational information bottleneck." It represents a new method that leverages the idea of maximum entropy of the learned probabilistic embedding to enhance the understanding and usage of word embeddings in Natural Language Processing (NLP) tasks.The main idea behind viB is to optimize the word vector (or word embedding) generation by learning a probabilistic model where the probability distribution over words is optimized for capturing word meanings. This method ensures that the learned word embeddings preserve the semantic structure of language while facilitating efficient parsing tasks.In concrete terms, viB optimizes the word embeddings such that the learned probability distribution over words maximizes the mutual information between words and their semantic context, while also minimizing the information that captures syntactic structure. This results in a more accurate representation of word meaning, benefiting applications in NLP like parsing.To clarify, the term "Extended Information Bottleneck (EIB)" is often used to refer to this concept, as it is a more comprehensive and refined approach compared to the standard IB.

title: Centering the Speech Community
abstract: How can NLP/AI practitioners engage with oral societies and develop locally appropriate language technologies? We report on our experience of working together over five years in a remote community in the far north of Australia, and how we prototyped simple language technologies to support our collaboration. We navigated different understandings of language, the functional differentiation of oral vs institutional languages, and the distinct technology opportunities for each. Our collaboration unsettled the first author’s western framing of language as data for exploitation by machines, and we devised a design pattern that seems better aligned with local interests and aspirations. We call for new collaborations on the design of locally appropriate technologies for languages with primary orality.

"Centering the Speech Community". कॉइनोप्ल, टॉम लैंज़ड के लिए जिस टूरिस्तिक डिवीजन से संवाद करता है।

title: Dolma: an Open Corpus of Three Trillion Tokens for Language Model Pretraining Research
abstract: Information about pretraining corpora used to train the current best-performing language models is seldom discussed: commercial models rarely detail their data, and even open models are often released without accompanying training data or recipes to reproduce them. As a result, it is challenging to conduct and advance scientific research on language modeling, such as understanding how training data impacts model capabilities and limitations. To facilitate scientific research on language model pretraining, we curate and release Dolma, a three-trillion-token English corpus, built from a diverse mixture of web content, scientific papers, code, public-domain books, social media, and encyclopedic materials. We extensively document Dolma, including its design principles, details about its construction, and a summary of its contents. We present analyses and experimental results on intermediate states of Dolma to share what we have learned about important data curation practices. Finally, we open-source our data curation toolkit to enable reproduction of our work as well as support further research in large-scale data curation.

output_text: स्वागत है! That's a whopping massive amount of text!To put it into perspective, Dolma corpus is one of the largest openly available text datasets, offering an unprecedented scale for language model researchers to explore and train on, which can lead to potentially more efficient and effective language models.

title: The Mechanical Bard: An Interpretable Machine Learning Approach to Shakespearean Sonnet Generation
abstract: We consider the automated generation of sonnets, a poetic form constrained according to meter, rhyme scheme, and length. Sonnets generally also use rhetorical figures, expressive language, and a consistent theme or narrative. Our constrained decoding approach allows for the generation of sonnets within preset poetic constraints, while using a relatively modest neural backbone. Human evaluation confirms that our approach produces Shakespearean sonnets that resemble human-authored sonnets, and which adhere to the genre’s defined constraints and contain lyrical language and literary devices.

output_text: The paper "The Mechanical Bard: An Interpretable Machine Learning Approach to Shakespearean Sonnet Generation" by Agnew, Edwin et al. published in a journal called PLOS (Platform for Open Science) One. Here, "poS" is an abbreviation for "PLOS One", which is a peer-reviewed open-access scientific journal.

title: Do PLMs Know and Understand Ontological Knowledge?
abstract: Ontological knowledge, which comprises classes and properties and their relationships, is integral to world knowledge. It is significant to explore whether Pretrained Language Models (PLMs) know and understand such knowledge. However, existing PLM-probing studies focus mainly on factual knowledge, lacking a system- atic probing of ontological knowledge. In this paper, we focus on probing whether PLMs store ontological knowledge and have a semantic un- derstanding of the knowledge rather than rote memorization of the surface form. To probe whether PLMs know ontological knowledge, we investigate how well PLMs memorize: (1) types of entities; (2) hierarchical relationships among classes and properties, e.g., Person is a subclass of Animal and Member of Sports Team is a subproperty of Member of ; (3) domain and range constraints of properties, e.g., the subject of Member of Sports Team should be a Person and the object should be a Sports Team. To further probe whether PLMs truly understand ontological knowledge beyond memorization, we comprehensively study whether they can reliably perform logical reasoning with given knowledge according to ontological entailment rules. Our probing results show that PLMs can memorize certain ontological knowledge and utilize implicit knowledge in reasoning. How- ever, both the memorizing and reasoning per- formances are less than perfect, indicating in- complete knowledge and understanding.

title: Semantic Sensitivities and Inconsistent Predictions: Measuring the Fragility of NLI Models
abstract: Recent studies of the emergent capabilities of transformer-based Natural Language Understanding (NLU) models have indicated that they have an understanding of lexical and compositional semantics. We provide evidence that suggests these claims should be taken with a grain of salt: we find that state-of-the-art Natural Language Inference (NLI) models are sensitive towards minor semantics preserving surface-form variations, which lead to sizable inconsistent model decisions during inference. Notably, this behaviour differs from valid and in-depth comprehension of compositional semantics, however does neither emerge when evaluating model accuracy on standard benchmarks nor when probing for syntactic, monotonic, and logically robust reasoning. We propose a novel framework to measure the extent of semantic sensitivity. To this end, we evaluate NLI models on adversarially generated examples containing minor semantics-preserving surface-form input noise. This is achieved using conditional text generation, with the explicit condition that the NLI model predicts the relationship between the original and adversarial inputs as a symmetric equivalence entailment. We systematically study the effects of the phenomenon across NLI models for \text{\emph{in-}} and \text{\emph{out-of-}} domain settings. Our experiments show that semantic sensitivity causes performance degradations of 12.92% and 23.71% average over \text{\emph{in-}} and \text{\emph{out-of-}} domain settings, respectively. We further perform ablation studies, analysing this phenomenon across models, datasets, and variations in inference and show that semantic sensitivity can lead to major inconsistency within model predictions.

"Semantic Sensitivities and Inconsistent Predictions: Measuring the Fragility of NLI Models" शीर्षक वाले लेख में नामित मॉडल के लिए "nlU" क्षेत्र को "Natural Language Understanding" के लिए खड़ा है, जो एक क्षेत्र है जिसने इंटर्नल मॉडल, चैटबॉट्स, नोटबुक प्रोग्रामिंग, और नेटवर्क-आधारित एक्शन सिस्टम जैसे का विकास किया है जो ध्यान केंद्रित करते हैं कि मशीनरी को भाषा भाषा में जानकारी सीखना है और उस पर बातचीत करने में सक्षम बनाना। निकटता से, nlU मॉडल, आमतौर पर कृत्रिम बुद्धिमत्ता (AI) रेंज में, एक संख्या में अनुप्रयोगों में प्रशिक्षित होते हैं, जिसमें सिर्फ खोज, भाषण में कार्रवाई की स्वचालित पहचान, ध्वनि स्निपेट का अनुक्रमण शामिल है।NL (Natural Language) का विस्तारित रूप "नेचरल लैंग्वेज इंटरप्रेटेशन" या मशीन लर्निंग मॉडल के लिए "नेचरल लैंग्वेज इन्टरप्रिटेशन" के रूप में खोजा जा सकता है। यह मानव भाषा में अर्थ साझा करने वाले व्याकरणिक संबंधों पर ध्यान केंद्रित करता है और उनके साथ बातचीत करने में मनुष्यों की योग्यताप्रदान करने के लिए मैकेनिज्म प्रदान करता है। NL मॉडल बातचीत को समझने, व्याख्यान में अर्थ निर्देशित करने, और उनके पुरस्कार सांख्यिकीय और भाषाई फ्रेमवर

title: Do LLMs Plan Like Human Writers? Comparing Journalist Coverage of Press Releases with LLMs
abstract: Journalists engage in multiple steps in the news writing process that depend on human creativity, like exploring different “angles” (i.e. the specific perspectives a reporter takes). These can potentially be aided by large language models (LLMs). By affecting planning decisions, such interventions can have an outsize impact on creative output. We advocate a careful approach to evaluating these interventions to ensure alignment with human values.In a case study of journalistic coverage of press releases, we assemble a large dataset of 250k press releases and 650k articles covering them. We develop methods to identify news articles that _challenge and contextualize_ press releases. Finally, we evaluate suggestions made by LLMs for these articles and compare these with decisions made by human journalists. Our findings are three-fold: (1) Human-written news articles that challenge and contextualize press releases more take more creative angles and use more informational sources. (2) LLMs align better with humans when recommending angles, compared with informational sources. (3) Both the angles and sources LLMs suggest are significantly less creative than humans.

output_text: मैंने लेख में 'Do LLMs Plan Like Human Writers?' Comparing Journalist Coverage of Press Releases with LLMs (Spangher, Alexander et al.) का उल्लेख करा है, जहाँ मुझे लगता है कि अंतर्राष्ट्रीय पत्रकारिता शोध एक न्यूयॉर्क पत्रिका में 'PressRelease' प्रस्तुत करती है। पत्रकारिता के विभिन्न कदमों को स्पष्ट करते हुए, मैं इसे खुले पाठकों के लिए संदर्भ के रूप में उपयोग कर सकता हूँ।

title: Entity Tracking in Language Models
abstract: Keeping track of how states of entities change as a text or dialog unfolds is a key prerequisite to discourse understanding. Yet, there have been few systematic investigations into the ability of large language models (LLMs) to track discourse entities. In this work, we present a task probing to what extent a language model can infer the final state of an entity given an English description of the initial state and a series of state-changing operations. We use this task to first investigate whether Flan-T5, GPT-3 and GPT-3.5 can track the state of entities, and find that only GPT-3.5 models, which have been pretrained on large amounts of code, exhibit this ability. We then investigate whether smaller models pretrained primarily on text can learn to track entities, through finetuning T5 on several training/evaluation splits. While performance degrades for more complex splits, we find that even when evaluated on a different set of entities from training or longer operation sequences, a finetuned model can perform non-trivial entity tracking. Taken together, these results suggest that language models can learn to track entities but pretraining on text corpora alone does not make this capacity surface.

title: Requirements and Motivations of Low-Resource Speech Synthesis for Language Revitalization
abstract: This paper describes the motivation and development of speech synthesis systems for the purposes of language revitalization. By building speech synthesis systems for three Indigenous languages spoken in Canada, Kanien’kéha, Gitksan & SENĆOŦEN, we re-evaluate the question of how much data is required to build low-resource speech synthesis systems featuring state-of-the-art neural models. For example, preliminary results with English data show that a FastSpeech2 model trained with 1 hour of training data can produce speech with comparable naturalness to a Tacotron2 model trained with 10 hours of data. Finally, we motivate future research in evaluation and classroom integration in the field of speech synthesis for language revitalization.

By building speech synthesis systems for three Indig

title: EconAgent: Large Language Model-Empowered Agents for Simulating Macroeconomic Activities
abstract: The advent of artificial intelligence has led to a growing emphasis on data-driven modeling in macroeconomics, with agent-based modeling (ABM) emerging as a prominent bottom-up simulation paradigm. In ABM, agents (*e.g.*, households, firms) interact within a macroeconomic environment, collectively generating market dynamics. Existing agent modeling typically employs predetermined rules or learning-based neural networks for decision-making. However, customizing each agent presents significant challenges, complicating the modeling of agent heterogeneity. Additionally, the influence of multi-period market dynamics and multifaceted macroeconomic factors are often overlooked in decision-making processes.In this work, we introduce **EconAgent**, a large language model-empowered agent with human-like characteristics for macroeconomic simulation. We first construct a simulation environment that incorporates various market dynamics driven by agents’ decisions regarding work and consumption. Through the perception module, we create heterogeneous agents with distinct decision-making mechanisms. Furthermore, we model the impact of macroeconomic trends using a memory module, which allows agents to reflect on past individual experiences and market dynamics.Simulation experiments show that EconAgent can make realistic decisions, leading to more reasonable macroeconomic phenomena compared to existing rule-based or learning-based agents. Our codes are released at https://github.com/tsinghua-fib-lab/ACL24-EconAgent.
question: DSGE का विस्तारित रूप क्या है?
prompt: "EconAgent: Large Language Model-Empowered Agents for Simulating Macroeconomic Activities" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Li,Nian et al. द्वारा, dsGE का विस्तारित रूप क्या है? यहाँ एक संक्षिप्त विवरण है, जहाँ आप संदर्भ के रूप में उपयोग कर सकते हैं: The advent of artificial intelligence has led to a growing emphasis on data-driven modeling in macroeconomics, with agent-based modeling (ABM) emerging as a prominent bottom-up
output_text: The expanded DS-GE framework as described in the article "EconAgent: Large Language Model-Powered Agents for Simulating Macroeconomic Activities" by Li et al. integrates aspects of both Data-Driven Structural General Equilibrium (DS-GE) models and agent-based modeling (ABM).DS-GE models, initially developed by Coen Teiletten and Frank Schorfheide, aim to combine the microfoundations of dynamic stochastic general equilibrium (DSGE) models with a data-driven approach. Their goal is to create more realistic and accurate macroeconomic simulations. DS-GE models use detailed micro-level data to validate and provide input for the corresponding macro-level models. The integration of machine learning (ML) and large language models (LLMs) has been proposed to further enhance the data-driven approach of DS-GE models.Agent-based modeling is another key component that the authors have incorporated into the DS-GE framework. ABM involves modeling economic systems at the level of specific agents, such as households, firms, or individuals, using artificial intelligence and data analysis techniques. This bottom-up approach can encompass a wide range of economic phenomena, allowing for the creation of highly detailed representations of societal behavior.By combining these two models, the expanded DS-GE setup offers a nuanced approach to simulating macroeconomic activities. It aims to better capture the dynamics and interdependencies present in real-world economic systems by integrating data-driven validation of behavioral rules and ABM techniques.

title: Specializing Word Embeddings (for Parsing) by Information Bottleneck
abstract: Pre-trained word embeddings like ELMo and BERT contain rich syntactic and semantic information, resulting in state-of-the-art performance on various tasks. We propose a very fast variational information bottleneck (VIB) method to nonlinearly compress these embeddings, keeping only the information that helps a discriminative parser. We compress each word embedding to either a discrete tag or a continuous vector. In the discrete version, our automatically compressed tags form an alternative tag set: we show experimentally that our tags capture most of the information in traditional POS tag annotations, but our tag sequences can be parsed more accurately at the same level of tag granularity. In the continuous version, we show experimentally that moderately compressing the word embeddings by our method yields a more accurate parser in 8 of 9 languages, unlike simple dimensionality reduction.

We propose a very fas

However, based on context and related concepts, it can be inferred or understood as "Very Informative Bottleneck". ViB is a novel approach that leverages the power of pre-trained word embeddings such as ELMo and BERT to improve parsing performance.

title: Centering the Speech Community
abstract: How can NLP/AI practitioners engage with oral societies and develop locally appropriate language technologies? We report on our experience of working together over five years in a remote community in the far north of Australia, and how we prototyped simple language technologies to support our collaboration. We navigated different understandings of language, the functional differentiation of oral vs institutional languages, and the distinct technology opportunities for each. Our collaboration unsettled the first author’s western framing of language as data for exploitation by machines, and we devised a design pattern that seems better aligned with local interests and aspirations. We call for new collaborations on the design of locally appropriate technologies for languages with primary orality.

title: Faithful Low-Resource Data-to-Text Generation through Cycle Training
abstract: Methods to generate text from structured data have advanced significantly in recent years, primarily due to fine-tuning of pre-trained language models on large datasets. However, such models can fail to produce output faithful to the input data, particularly on out-of-domain data. Sufficient annotated data is often not available for specific domains, leading us to seek an unsupervised approach to improve the faithfulness of output text. Since the problem is fundamentally one of consistency between the representations of the structured data and text, we evaluate the effectiveness of cycle training in this work. Cycle training uses two models which are inverses of each other: one that generates text from structured data, and one which generates the structured data from natural language text. We show that cycle training, when initialized with a small amount of supervised data (100 samples in our case), achieves nearly the same performance as fully supervised approaches for the data-to-text generation task on the WebNLG, E2E, WTQ, and WSQL datasets. We perform extensive empirical analysis with automated evaluation metrics and a newly designed human evaluation schema to reveal different cycle training strategies’ effectiveness of reducing various types of generation errors. Our code is publicly available at https://github.com/Edillower/CycleNLG.

However
output_text: Table 1 in the paper "Faithful Low-Resource Data-to-Text Generation through Cycle Training" by Wang, Zhuoer et al. mentions the following datasets:1. **WikiText**: A widely used dataset for language modeling, which consists of text from Wikipedia and contains 28 million articles.2. **Pascal VOC**: A dataset of annotated images of various objects, which is commonly used for object detection tasks in computer vision. In the context of this paper, Pascal VOC is used in relation to the text generation task, where the goal is to summarize these images in a concise text.3. **Common Crawl**: A dataset of web pages, which can be used for natural language processing and web mining tasks.4. **Wikipedia**: A vast repository of Wikipedia articles, which is used for generating text through fine-tuning of pre-trained language models.As the authors note, fine-tuning these pre-trained language models on large datasets (like these ones) is crucial for advancing the methodology of generating text from structured data effectively.

title: The Mechanical Bard: An Interpretable Machine Learning Approach to Shakespearean Sonnet Generation
abstract: We consider the automated generation of sonnets, a poetic form constrained according to meter, rhyme scheme, and length. Sonnets generally also use rhetorical figures, expressive language, and a consistent theme or narrative. Our constrained decoding approach allows for the generation of sonnets within preset poetic constraints, while using a relatively modest neural backbone. Human evaluation confirms that our approach produces Shakespearean sonnets that resemble human-authored sonnets, and which adhere to the genre’s defined constraints and contain lyrical language and literary devices.

Sonnets generally also use rhetorical figures, expressiv
output_text: विस्तारित पोस देता है- 0.7650अपने रचना में, Agnew, Edwin और उनकी सहयोगी PoS (अंग्रेजी अक्षर संघारा वर्ग) के साथ स्वचालित शेक्सपियररी सोनेट उत्पन्न करने की खोज में शामिल हुए। रचना या 'मैकेनिकल बार्ड' एक खोजी अनुप्रयोग है जो विशेष रूप से स्वतंत्र स्वर के साथ स्वतंत्र सिद्धांतों को खोजने के लिए पैटर्न मॉड्यूल का उपयोग करता है। यह तकनीक कुशल है क्योंकि यह तीन प्रमुख कारकों के हिसाब से एक संस्करण जेनरेट कर सकता है- स्वर का चयन, पैटर्न का व्यवहार, और अक्षर गणना। नज़रियाबंद के साथ ही, ये सिद्धांत स्वतंत्र रूप से एक सामान्य वाक्य को स्वरों और अक्षरों के सिलसिले में बदल सकते हैं, स्वतंत्र हैं।रचक सोनेट, रचना का एक क्षेत्र, एक संसार के साथ है जिसमें नियम हैं। यह शेक्सपियरियाई बार्ड भी अक्सर कुछ अनूठे आंकड़े (संसार का उपयोग करते हुए) और गहरी भावनाओं के व्यापक विश्लेषण का उपयोग करता है।"मैकेनिकल बार्ड के संदर्भ में, हम इस सिद्धांत का उपयोग करते हैं ताकि दो कारकों के रूप में एक संस्करण बनाएं - संसार अनुकूलन (पैटर्न जिसमें जानकारी होती है) और संसार प्रसाधक। यह द्विदिश अनुरूप और अद्वितीय संस्करणों से जो

title: Do PLMs Know and Understand Ontological Knowledge?
abstract: Ontological knowledge, which comprises classes and properties and their relationships, is integral to world knowledge. It is significant to explore whether Pretrained Language Models (PLMs) know and understand such knowledge. However, existing PLM-probing studies focus mainly on factual knowledge, lacking a system- atic probing of ontological knowledge. In this paper, we focus on probing whether PLMs store ontological knowledge and have a semantic un- derstanding of the knowledge rather than rote memorization of the surface form. To probe whether PLMs know ontological knowledge, we investigate how well PLMs memorize: (1) types of entities; (2) hierarchical relationships among classes and properties, e.g., Person is a subclass of Animal and Member of Sports Team is a subproperty of Member of ; (3) domain and range constraints of properties, e.g., the subject of Member of Sports Team should be a Person and the object should be a Sports Team. To further probe whether PLMs truly understand ontological knowledge beyond memorization, we comprehensively study whether they can reliably perform logical reasoning with given knowledge according to ontological entailment rules. Our probing results show that PLMs can memorize certain ontological knowledge and utilize implicit knowledge in reasoning. How- ever, both the memorizing and reasoning per- formances are less than perfect, indicating in- complete knowledge and understanding.

It is significant to explore whether Pretrained Language M
output_text: Table 1 in the article "Do PLMs Know and Understand Ontological Knowledge?" by Wu, Weiqi et al. lists 10 tasks that are explored to assess the understanding of ontological knowledge by Pretrained Language Models (PLMs).

title: Quantized Side Tuning: Fast and Memory-Efficient Tuning of Quantized Large Language Models
abstract: Finetuning large language models (LLMs) has been empirically effective on a variety of downstream tasks. Existing approaches to finetuning an LLM either focus on parameter-efficient finetuning, which only updates a small number of trainable parameters, or attempt to reduce the memory footprint during the training phase of the finetuning. Typically, the memory footprint during finetuning stems from three contributors: model weights, optimizer states, and intermediate activations. However, existing works still require considerable memory, and none can simultaneously mitigate the memory footprint of all three sources. In this paper, we present quantized side tuing (QST), which enables memory-efficient and fast finetuning of LLMs by operating through a dual-stage process. First, QST quantizes an LLM’s model weights into 4-bit to reduce the memory footprint of the LLM’s original weights. Second, QST introduces a side network separated from the LLM, which utilizes the hidden states of the LLM to make task-specific predictions. Using a separate side network avoids performing back-propagation through the LLM, thus reducing the memory requirement of the intermediate activations. Finally, QST leverages several low-rank adaptors and gradient-free downsample modules to significantly reduce the trainable parameters, so as to save the memory footprint of the optimizer states. Experiments show that QST can reduce the total memory footprint by up to 2.3× and speed up the finetuning process by up to 3\times while achieving competent performance compared with the state-of-the-art. When it comes to full finetuning, QST can reduce the total memory footprint up to 7\times.

prompt: "Quantized Side Tuning: Fast and Memory-Efficient Tuning of Quantized Large Language Models" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Zhang,Zhengxin et al. द्वारा, abstract के अनुसार, QST total memory footprint को कितना कम कर सकता है?
output_text: According to the abstract of the paper "Quantized Side Tuning: Fast and Memory-Efficient Tuning of Quantized Large Language Models" by Zhang, Zhengxin et al., the Quantized Side Tuning (QST) approach can significantly reduce the total memory footprint. Specifically, it is stated that QST can reduce the memory footprint by up to 4x compared to the original quantized model, while maintaining the same level of accuracy.

title: Do LLMs Plan Like Human Writers? Comparing Journalist Coverage of Press Releases with LLMs
abstract: Journalists engage in multiple steps in the news writing process that depend on human creativity, like exploring different “angles” (i.e. the specific perspectives a reporter takes). These can potentially be aided by large language models (LLMs). By affecting planning decisions, such interventions can have an outsize impact on creative output. We advocate a careful approach to evaluating these interventions to ensure alignment with human values.In a case study of journalistic coverage of press releases, we assemble a large dataset of 250k press releases and 650k articles covering them. We develop methods to identify news articles that _challenge and contextualize_ press releases. Finally, we evaluate suggestions made by LLMs for these articles and compare these with decisions made by human journalists. Our findings are three-fold: (1) Human-written news articles that challenge and contextualize press releases more take more creative angles and use more informational sources. (2) LLMs align better with humans when recommending angles, compared with informational sources. (3) Both the angles and sources LLMs suggest are significantly less creative than humans.
question: यह हस्तलिपि, PressRelease प्रस्तुत करती है, जो press releases से जुड़े समाचार लेखों का एक विशाल संग्रह है। लेखक कितने समाचार लेखों और press releases पर विचार करते हैं?

output_text: The authors of the article, Spangher, Alexander et al., analyze a vast collection of news articles related to press releases, which they refer to as "PressRelease". They examine a total of 1,200 news articles and 1,200 press releases.

title: Entity Tracking in Language Models
abstract: Keeping track of how states of entities change as a text or dialog unfolds is a key prerequisite to discourse understanding. Yet, there have been few systematic investigations into the ability of large language models (LLMs) to track discourse entities. In this work, we present a task probing to what extent a language model can infer the final state of an entity given an English description of the initial state and a series of state-changing operations. We use this task to first investigate whether Flan-T5, GPT-3 and GPT-3.5 can track the state of entities, and find that only GPT-3.5 models, which have been pretrained on large amounts of code, exhibit this ability. We then investigate whether smaller models pretrained primarily on text can learn to track entities, through finetuning T5 on several training/evaluation splits. While performance degrades for more complex splits, we find that even when evaluated on a different set of entities from training or longer operation sequences, a finetuned model can perform non-trivial entity tracking. Taken together, these results suggest that language models can learn to track entities but pretraining on text corpora alone does not make this capacity surface.

output_text: According to Table 1 in the paper "Entity Tracking in Language Models" by Kim, Najoung et al., they used 5 models for in-context demonstration experiments.

title: EconAgent: Large Language Model-Empowered Agents for Simulating Macroeconomic Activities
abstract: The advent of artificial intelligence has led to a growing emphasis on data-driven modeling in macroeconomics, with agent-based modeling (ABM) emerging as a prominent bottom-up simulation paradigm. In ABM, agents (*e.g.*, households, firms) interact within a macroeconomic environment, collectively generating market dynamics. Existing agent modeling typically employs predetermined rules or learning-based neural networks for decision-making. However, customizing each agent presents significant challenges, complicating the modeling of agent heterogeneity. Additionally, the influence of multi-period market dynamics and multifaceted macroeconomic factors are often overlooked in decision-making processes.In this work, we introduce **EconAgent**, a large language model-empowered agent with human-like characteristics for macroeconomic simulation. We first construct a simulation environment that incorporates various market dynamics driven by agents’ decisions regarding work and consumption. Through the perception module, we create heterogeneous agents with distinct decision-making mechanisms. Furthermore, we model the impact of macroeconomic trends using a memory module, which allows agents to reflect on past individual experiences and market dynamics.Simulation experiments show that EconAgent can make realistic decisions, leading to more reasonable macroeconomic phenomena compared to existing rule-based or learning-based agents. Our codes are released at https://github.com/tsinghua-fib-lab/ACL24-EconAgent.
question: DSGE का विस्तारित रूप क्या है?
prompt: "EconAgent: Large Language Model-Empowered Agents for Simulating Macroeconomic Activities" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Li,Nian et al. द्वारा, dsGE का विस्तारित रूप क्या है?
output_text: The article "EconAgent: Large Language Model-Empowered Agents for Simulating Macroeconomic Activities" by Li, Nian et al. discusses the extension of Dynamic Stochastic General Equilibrium (DSGE) models using Large Language Models (LLMs). DSGE models are a type of macroeconomic model that combines elements of general equilibrium theory and dynamic stochastic models. They are widely used in economics to study the behavior of economic systems and make predictions about future economic outcomes. However, DSGE models have some limitations, such as the difficulty in incorporating complex economic behaviors and the need for manual calibration of model parameters.To address these limitations, the authors propose the use of LLMs to extend DSGE models. LLMs are a type of artificial intelligence model that can process and generate human-like language. They have been shown to be effective in tasks such as language translation, text summarization, and question answering.In the context of DSGE models, LLMs can be used to simulate the behavior of economic agents, such as households and firms, in a more realistic and flexible way. For example, LLMs can be trained on large datasets of economic data and then used to generate responses to economic stimuli, such as changes in interest rates or government spending. This can help to improve the accuracy and realism of DSGE model simulations.The authors also discuss the potential applications of LLM-empowered DSGE models in areas such as macroeconomic forecasting, policy analysis, and economic scenario planning. They argue that these models can provide more accurate and nuanced predictions of economic outcomes, and can be used to evaluate the impact of different policy interventions.Overall, the article presents a promising approach to extending the capabilities of DSGE models using LLMs, and highlights the potential benefits of this approach for improving the accuracy and realism of macroeconomic simulations.

title: Don’t Blame the Annotator: Bias Already Starts in the Annotation Instructions
abstract: In recent years, progress in NLU has been driven by benchmarks. These benchmarks are typically collected by crowdsourcing, where annotators write examples based on annotation instructions crafted by dataset creators. In this work, we hypothesize that annotators pick up on patterns in the crowdsourcing instructions, which bias them to write many similar examples that are then over-represented in the collected data. We study this form of bias, termed instruction bias, in 14 recent NLU benchmarks, showing that instruction examples often exhibit concrete patterns, which are propagated by crowdworkers to the collected data. This extends previous work (Geva et al., 2019) and raises a new concern of whether we are modeling the dataset creator’s instructions, rather than the task. Through a series of experiments, we show that, indeed, instruction bias can lead to overestimation of model performance, and that models struggle to generalize beyond biases originating in the crowdsourcing instructions. We further analyze the influence of instruction bias in terms of pattern frequency and model size, and derive concrete recommendations for creating future NLU benchmarks.
question: Abstract के अनुसार, instruction bias का अध्ययन कितने NLU benchmarks में किया गया है।
prompt: "Don’t Blame the Annotator: Bias Already Starts in the Annotation Instructions" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Parmar,Mihir et al. द्वारा, abstract के अनुसार, instruction bias का अध्ययन कितने NLU benchmarks में किया गया है।
output_text: According to the abstract of the paper "Don’t Blame the Annotator: Bias Already Starts in the Annotation Instructions" by Parmar, Mihir et al., the study of instruction bias has been conducted in multiple NLU (Natural Language Understanding) benchmarks. However, the exact number of benchmarks is not specified in the abstract.

title: Faithful Low-Resource Data-to-Text Generation through Cycle Training
abstract: Methods to generate text from structured data have advanced significantly in recent years, primarily due to fine-tuning of pre-trained language models on large datasets. However, such models can fail to produce output faithful to the input data, particularly on out-of-domain data. Sufficient annotated data is often not available for specific domains, leading us to seek an unsupervised approach to improve the faithfulness of output text. Since the problem is fundamentally one of consistency between the representations of the structured data and text, we evaluate the effectiveness of cycle training in this work. Cycle training uses two models which are inverses of each other: one that generates text from structured data, and one which generates the structured data from natural language text. We show that cycle training, when initialized with a small amount of supervised data (100 samples in our case), achieves nearly the same performance as fully supervised approaches for the data-to-text generation task on the WebNLG, E2E, WTQ, and WSQL datasets. We perform extensive empirical analysis with automated evaluation metrics and a newly designed human evaluation schema to reveal different cycle training strategies’ effectiveness of reducing various types of generation errors. Our code is publicly available at https://github.com/Edillower/CycleNLG.
question: तालिका 1 में कौन कौन से datasets का उल्लेख किया गया है?
prompt: "Faithful Low-Resource Data-to-Text Generation through Cycle Training" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Wang,Zhuoer et al. द्वारा, तालिका 1 में कौन कौन से datasets का उल्लेख किया गया है?
output_text: According to Table 1 in the paper "Faithful Low-Resource Data-to-Text Generation through Cycle Training" by Wang, Zhuoer et al., the following datasets are mentioned:1. **WikiText**: A dataset of text from Wikipedia articles.2. **BookCorpus**: A dataset of text from books.3. **Common Crawl**: A dataset of web pages.4. **OpenWebText**: A dataset of web pages.5. **CC-News**: A dataset of news articles.6. **CC-Books**: A dataset of book text.7. **CC-Web**: A dataset of web pages.8. **CC-News**: A dataset of news articles.9. **CC-Books**: A dataset of book text.10. **CC-Web**: A dataset of web pages.These datasets are used to evaluate the performance of the proposed cycle training method for data-to-text generation in low-resource settings.

title: CHECKWHY: Causal Fact Verification via Argument Structure
abstract: With the growing complexity of fact verification tasks, the concern with “thoughtful” reasoning capabilities is increasing. However, recent fact verification benchmarks mainly focus on checking a narrow scope of semantic factoids within claims and lack an explicit logical reasoning process. In this paper, we introduce CHECKWHY, a challenging dataset tailored to a novel causal fact verification task: checking the truthfulness of the causal relation within claims through rigorous reasoning steps. CHECKWHY consists of over 19K “why” claim-evidence- argument structure triplets with supports, refutes, and not enough info labels. Each argument structure is composed of connected evidence, representing the reasoning process that begins with foundational evidence and progresses toward claim establishment. Through extensive experiments on state-of-the-art models, we validate the importance of incorporating the argument structure for causal fact verification. Moreover, the automated and human evaluation of argument structure generation reveals the difficulty in producing satisfying argument structure by fine-tuned models or Chain-of-Thought prompted LLMs, leaving considerable room for future improvements.

title: Dolma: an Open Corpus of Three Trillion Tokens for Language Model Pretraining Research

As a result, it is challenging to conduct and advance scientific research on language modeling, such as understanding how training data impacts model capabilities and limitations. To facilitate scientific research on language model pretraining, we curate and release Dolma, a three-trillion-token English corpus, built from a diverse mixture of web content, scientific papers, code, public-domain books, social media, and encyclopedic materials. We extensively document Dolma, including its design principles, details about its construction, and a summary of its contents. title: The Mechanical Bard: An Interpretable Machine Learning Approach to Shakespearean Sonnet Generation
abstract: We consider the automated generation of sonnets, a poetic form constrained according to meter, rhyme scheme, and length. Sonnets generally also use rhetorical figures, expressive language, and a consistent theme or narrative. Our constrained decoding approach allows for the generation of sonnets within preset poetic constraints, while using a relatively modest neural backbone. Human evaluation confirms that our approach produces Shakespearean sonnets that resemble human-authored sonnets, and which adhere to the genre’s defined constraints and contain lyrical language and literary devices.

title: Quantized Side Tuning: Fast and Memory-Efficient Tuning of Quantized Large Language Models
abstract: Finetuning large language models (LLMs) has been empirically effective on a variety of downstream tasks. Existing approaches to finetuning an LLM either focus on parameter-efficient finetuning, which only updates a small number of trainable parameters, or attempt to reduce the memory footprint during the training phase of the finetuning. Typically, the memory footprint during finetuning stems from three contributors: model weights, optimizer states, and intermediate activations. However, existing works still require considerable memory, and none can simultaneously mitigate the memory footprint of all three sources. In this paper, we present quantized side tuing (QST), which enables memory-efficient and fast finetuning of LLMs by operating through a dual-stage process. First, QST quantizes an LLM’s model weights into 4-bit to reduce the memory footprint of the LLM’s original weights. Second, QST introduces a side network separated from the LLM, which utilizes the hidden states of the LLM to make task-specific predictions. Using a separate side network avoids performing back-propagation through the LLM, thus reducing the memory requirement of the intermediate activations. Finally, QST leverages several low-rank adaptors and gradient-free downsample modules to significantly reduce the trainable parameters, so as to save the memory footprint of the optimizer states. Experiments show that QST can reduce the total memory footprint by up to 2.3× and speed up the finetuning process by up to 3\times while achieving competent performance compared with the state-of-the-art. When it comes to full finetuning, QST can reduce the total memory footprint up to 7\times.

title: Semantic Sensitivities and Inconsistent Predictions: Measuring the Fragility of NLI Models
abstract: Recent studies of the emergent capabilities of transformer-based Natural Language Understanding (NLU) models have indicated that they have an understanding of lexical and compositional semantics. We provide evidence that suggests these claims should be taken with a grain of salt: we find that state-of-the-art Natural Language Inference (NLI) models are sensitive towards minor semantics preserving surface-form variations, which lead to sizable inconsistent model decisions during inference. Notably, this behaviour differs from valid and in-depth comprehension of compositional semantics, however does neither emerge when evaluating model accuracy on standard benchmarks nor when probing for syntactic, monotonic, and logically robust reasoning. We propose a novel framework to measure the extent of semantic sensitivity. To this end, we evaluate NLI models on adversarially generated examples containing minor semantics-preserving surface-form input noise. This is achieved using conditional text generation, with the explicit condition that the NLI model predicts the relationship between the original and adversarial inputs as a symmetric equivalence entailment. We systematically study the effects of the phenomenon across NLI models for \text{\emph{in-}} and \text{\emph{out-of-}} domain settings. Our experiments show that semantic sensitivity causes performance degradations of 12.92% and 23.71% average over \text{\emph{in-}} and \text{\emph{out-of-}} domain settings, respectively. We further perform ablation studies, analysing this phenomenon across models, datasets, and variations in inference and show that semantic sensitivity can lead to major inconsistency within model predictions.

output_text: The authors of the paper, Arakelyan, Erik et al., are discussing the capabilities of transformer-based Natural Language Understanding (NLU) models. Here's a brief explanation of what NLU and NLI are, along with their expanded forms:1. **Natural Language Understanding (NLU)**: NLU refers to the ability of a computer program or model to comprehend and interpret human language, including its meaning, context, and nuances. In the context of AI and machine learning, NLU is a crucial component of natural language processing (NLP) that enables machines to understand and respond to human input in a meaningful way.Expanded form: **Transformer-based NLU models**: These are advanced AI models that utilize the transformer architecture, a type of neural network designed specifically for processing sequential data such as text. These models have been shown to possess impressive capabilities in understanding natural language, including lexical and compositional semantics.2. **Natural Language Inference (NLI)**: NLI is a specific task within NLU that involves determining whether a given statement logically follows from a given premise. In other words, NLI models are trained to determine whether a conclusion logically follows from a given statement or not.Expanded form: **nlU and NLI**: The authors are likely referring to the expanded forms of NLU and NLI, which involve the application of NLU models to NLI tasks. This means that the models are trained to not only understand natural language but also to make logical inferences based on that understanding.In the context of the paper, the authors are discussing the fragility of these NLU and NLI models, highlighting their limitations and inconsistencies in making predictions.

title: RomanSetu: Efficiently unlocking multilingual capabilities of Large Language Models via Romanization
abstract: This study addresses the challenge of extending Large Language Models (LLMs) to non-English languages, specifically those using non-Roman scripts. We propose an approach that utilizes the romanized form of text as an interface for LLMs, hypothesizing that its frequent informal use and shared tokens with English enhance cross-lingual alignment. Our approach involve the continual pretraining of a English LLM like Llama 2 on romanized text of non-English, non-Roman script languages, followed by instruction tuning on romanized data. The results indicate that romanized text not only reduces token fertility by 2x-4x but also matches if not outperforms native script representation across various NLU, NLG and MT tasks. Moreover, the embeddings computed on romanized text exhibit closer alignment with their English translations than those from the native script. Our approach presents a promising direction for leveraging the power of English LLMs in languages traditionally underrepresented in NLP research.

title: Requirements and Motivations of Low-Resource Speech Synthesis for Language Revitalization
abstract: This paper describes the motivation and development of speech synthesis systems for the purposes of language revitalization. By building speech synthesis systems for three Indigenous languages spoken in Canada, Kanien’kéha, Gitksan & SENĆOŦEN, we re-evaluate the question of how much data is required to build low-resource speech synthesis systems featuring state-of-the-art neural models. For example, preliminary results with English data show that a FastSpeech2 model trained with 1 hour of training data can produce speech with comparable naturalness to a Tacotron2 model trained with 10 hours of data. Finally, we motivate future research in evaluation and classroom integration in the field of speech synthesis for language revitalization.

title: Don’t Blame the Annotator: Bias Already Starts in the Annotation Instructions
abstract: In recent years, progress in NLU has been driven by benchmarks. These benchmarks are typically collected by crowdsourcing, where annotators write examples based on annotation instructions crafted by dataset creators. In this work, we hypothesize that annotators pick up on patterns in the crowdsourcing instructions, which bias them to write many similar examples that are then over-represented in the collected data. We study this form of bias, termed instruction bias, in 14 recent NLU benchmarks, showing that instruction examples often exhibit concrete patterns, which are propagated by crowdworkers to the collected data. This extends previous work (Geva et al., 2019) and raises a new concern of whether we are modeling the dataset creator’s instructions, rather than the task. Through a series of experiments, we show that, indeed, instruction bias can lead to overestimation of model performance, and that models struggle to generalize beyond biases originating in the crowdsourcing instructions. We further analyze the influence of instruction bias in terms of pattern frequency and model size, and derive concrete recommendations for creating future NLU benchmarks.

title: Specializing Word Embeddings (for Parsing) by Information Bottleneck
abstract: Pre-trained word embeddings like ELMo and BERT contain rich syntactic and semantic information, resulting in state-of-the-art performance on various tasks. We propose a very fast variational information bottleneck (VIB) method to nonlinearly compress these embeddings, keeping only the information that helps a discriminative parser. We compress each word embedding to either a discrete tag or a continuous vector. In the discrete version, our automatically compressed tags form an alternative tag set: we show experimentally that our tags capture most of the information in traditional POS tag annotations, but our tag sequences can be parsed more accurately at the same level of tag granularity. In the continuous version, we show experimentally that moderately compressing the word embeddings by our method yields a more accurate parser in 8 of 9 languages, unlike simple dimensionality reduction.

title: Faithful Low-Resource Data-to-Text Generation through Cycle Training
abstract: Methods to generate text from structured data have advanced significantly in recent years, primarily due to fine-tuning of pre-trained language models on large datasets. However, such models can fail to produce output faithful to the input data, particularly on out-of-domain data. Sufficient annotated data is often not available for specific domains, leading us to seek an unsupervised approach to improve the faithfulness of output text. Since the problem is fundamentally one of consistency between the representations of the structured data and text, we evaluate the effectiveness of cycle training in this work. Cycle training uses two models which are inverses of each other: one that generates text from structured data, and one which generates the structured data from natural language text. We show that cycle training, when initialized with a small amount of supervised data (100 samples in our case), achieves nearly the same performance as fully supervised approaches for the data-to-text generation task on the WebNLG, E2E, WTQ, and WSQL datasets. We perform extensive empirical analysis with automated evaluation metrics and a newly designed human evaluation schema to reveal different cycle training strategies’ effectiveness of reducing various types of generation errors. Our code is publicly available at https://github.com/Edillower/CycleNLG.

title: CHECKWHY: Causal Fact Verification via Argument Structure
abstract: With the growing complexity of fact verification tasks, the concern with “thoughtful” reasoning capabilities is increasing. However, recent fact verification benchmarks mainly focus on checking a narrow scope of semantic factoids within claims and lack an explicit logical reasoning process. In this paper, we introduce CHECKWHY, a challenging dataset tailored to a novel causal fact verification task: checking the truthfulness of the causal relation within claims through rigorous reasoning steps. CHECKWHY consists of over 19K “why” claim-evidence- argument structure triplets with supports, refutes, and not enough info labels. Each argument structure is composed of connected evidence, representing the reasoning process that begins with foundational evidence and progresses toward claim establishment. Through extensive experiments on state-of-the-art models, we validate the importance of incorporating the argument structure for causal fact verification. Moreover, the automated and human evaluation of argument structure generation reveals the difficulty in producing satisfying argument structure by fine-tuned models or Chain-of-Thought prompted LLMs, leaving considerable room for future improvements.

title: Do PLMs Know and Understand Ontological Knowledge?
abstract: Ontological knowledge, which comprises classes and properties and their relationships, is integral to world knowledge. It is significant to explore whether Pretrained Language Models (PLMs) know and understand such knowledge. However, existing PLM-probing studies focus mainly on factual knowledge, lacking a system- atic probing of ontological knowledge. In this paper, we focus on probing whether PLMs store ontological knowledge and have a semantic un- derstanding of the knowledge rather than rote memorization of the surface form. To probe whether PLMs know ontological knowledge, we investigate how well PLMs memorize: (1) types of entities; (2) hierarchical relationships among classes and properties, e.g., Person is a subclass of Animal and Member of Sports Team is a subproperty of Member of ; (3) domain and range constraints of properties, e.g., the subject of Member of Sports Team should be a Person and the object should be a Sports Team. To further probe whether PLMs truly understand ontological knowledge beyond memorization, we comprehensively study whether they can reliably perform logical reasoning with given knowledge according to ontological entailment rules. Our probing results show that PLMs can memorize certain ontological knowledge and utilize implicit knowledge in reasoning. How- ever, both the memorizing and reasoning per- formances are less than perfect, indicating in- complete knowledge and understanding.

title: Entity Tracking in Language Models
abstract: Keeping track of how states of entities change as a text or dialog unfolds is a key prerequisite to discourse understanding. Yet, there have been few systematic investigations into the ability of large language models (LLMs) to track discourse entities. In this work, we present a task probing to what extent a language model can infer the final state of an entity given an English description of the initial state and a series of state-changing operations. We use this task to first investigate whether Flan-T5, GPT-3 and GPT-3.5 can track the state of entities, and find that only GPT-3.5 models, which have been pretrained on large amounts of code, exhibit this ability. We then investigate whether smaller models pretrained primarily on text can learn to track entities, through finetuning T5 on several training/evaluation splits. While performance degrades for more complex splits, we find that even when evaluated on a different set of entities from training or longer operation sequences, a finetuned model can perform non-trivial entity tracking. Taken together, these results suggest that language models can learn to track entities but pretraining on text corpora alone does not make this capacity surface.

title: RomanSetu: Efficiently unlocking multilingual capabilities of Large Language Models via Romanization
abstract: This study addresses the challenge of extending Large Language Models (LLMs) to non-English languages, specifically those using non-Roman scripts. We propose an approach that utilizes the romanized form of text as an interface for LLMs, hypothesizing that its frequent informal use and shared tokens with English enhance cross-lingual alignment. Our approach involve the continual pretraining of a English LLM like Llama 2 on romanized text of non-English, non-Roman script languages, followed by instruction tuning on romanized data. The results indicate that romanized text not only reduces token fertility by 2x-4x but also matches if not outperforms native script representation across various NLU, NLG and MT tasks. Moreover, the embeddings computed on romanized text exhibit closer alignment with their English translations than those from the native script. Our approach presents a promising direction for leveraging the power of English LLMs in languages traditionally underrepresented in NLP research.

title: Requirements and Motivations of Low-Resource Speech Synthesis for Language Revitalization
abstract: This paper describes the motivation and development of speech synthesis systems for the purposes of language revitalization. By building speech synthesis systems for three Indigenous languages spoken in Canada, Kanien’kéha, Gitksan & SENĆOŦEN, we re-evaluate the question of how much data is required to build low-resource speech synthesis systems featuring state-of-the-art neural models. For example, preliminary results with English data show that a FastSpeech2 model trained with 1 hour of training data can produce speech with comparable naturalness to a Tacotron2 model trained with 10 hours of data. Finally, we motivate future research in evaluation and classroom integration in the field of speech synthesis for language revitalization.

title: EconAgent: Large Language Model-Empowered Agents for Simulating Macroeconomic Activities
abstract: The advent of artificial intelligence has led to a growing emphasis on data-driven modeling in macroeconomics, with agent-based modeling (ABM) emerging as a prominent bottom-up simulation paradigm. In ABM, agents (*e.g.*, households, firms) interact within a macroeconomic environment, collectively generating market dynamics. Existing agent modeling typically employs predetermined rules or learning-based neural networks for decision-making. However, customizing each agent presents significant challenges, complicating the modeling of agent heterogeneity. Additionally, the influence of multi-period market dynamics and multifaceted macroeconomic factors are often overlooked in decision-making processes.In this work, we introduce **EconAgent**, a large language model-empowered agent with human-like characteristics for macroeconomic simulation. We first construct a simulation environment that incorporates various market dynamics driven by agents’ decisions regarding work and consumption. Through the perception module, we create heterogeneous agents with distinct decision-making mechanisms. Furthermore, we model the impact of macroeconomic trends using a memory module, which allows agents to reflect on past individual experiences and market dynamics.Simulation experiments show that EconAgent can make realistic decisions, leading to more reasonable macroeconomic phenomena compared to existing rule-based or learning-based agents. Our codes are released at https://github.com/tsinghua-fib-lab/ACL24-EconAgent.

title: Centering the Speech Community
abstract: How can NLP/AI practitioners engage with oral societies and develop locally appropriate language technologies? We report on our experience of working together over five years in a remote community in the far north of Australia, and how we prototyped simple language technologies to support our collaboration. We navigated different understandings of language, the functional differentiation of oral vs institutional languages, and the distinct technology opportunities for each. Our collaboration unsettled the first author’s western framing of language as data for exploitation by machines, and we devised a design pattern that seems better aligned with local interests and aspirations. We call for new collaborations on the design of locally appropriate technologies for languages with primary orality.

output_text: "Centering the Speech Community" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Bird,Steven et al. द्वारा, चित्र 1 में कितने Institutional Languages पर विचार किया गया है ?The article "The Importance of Institutions in the Development of a Speaking Community", written by Bird and Stevan, discusses the importance of institutions in developing a speaking community. लेख का तर्क है कि संस्थानों का विकास एक बोलने वाले समुदाय के विकास के लिए महत्वपूर्ण है, क्योंकि वे एक साझा भाषा के उपयोग को बढ़ावा देते हैं और एक समुदाय की पहचान को मजबूत करते हैं। The article also discuss the role of language policy in promoting the development of speaking communities."The Role of Language Policy in Promoting Speaker Identity" लेख शीर्षक वाले लेख, बर्ड और स्टीवन द्वारा लिखा गया, एक वक्ता की भाषा की भूमिका पर चर्चा करता है। According to the article, language policies play a crucial role in shaping the identity of speakers of the language. भाषा नीतियाॅ वक्तास्प की सांस्कृतिक पहचान और सामाजिक स्थिति को प्रभावित कर सकती है और वक्तस�� एकभाषी या द्विभाषी हो सकते हैं या नहीं।In conclusion, the two articles, "Institutionalizing a Language" and "Speaker's Identity and Language Policies," discuss different aspects of institutionalization and language development. "इंस्टीट्यूशनलाइजिंग ए लैंग्वेज" में, लेखक एक भाषा को संस्थागत बनाने के महत्व पर जोर देते है जबकि "स्पीकर आइडेंटिटी एंड लैंग्वेज पॉलिसीज़" वक्तार की आइडियথ और भाषा नीतियों के बीच के सम्बन्ध पर प्रकाश डालता है.

title: Do PLMs Know and Understand Ontological Knowledge?
abstract: Ontological knowledge, which comprises classes and properties and their relationships, is integral to world knowledge. It is significant to explore whether Pretrained Language Models (PLMs) know and understand such knowledge. However, existing PLM-probing studies focus mainly on factual knowledge, lacking a system- atic probing of ontological knowledge. In this paper, we focus on probing whether PLMs store ontological knowledge and have a semantic un- derstanding of the knowledge rather than rote memorization of the surface form. To probe whether PLMs know ontological knowledge, we investigate how well PLMs memorize: (1) types of entities; (2) hierarchical relationships among classes and properties, e.g., Person is a subclass of Animal and Member of Sports Team is a subproperty of Member of ; (3) domain and range constraints of properties, e.g., the subject of Member of Sports Team should be a Person and the object should be a Sports Team. To further probe whether PLMs truly understand ontological knowledge beyond memorization, we comprehensively study whether they can reliably perform logical reasoning with given knowledge according to ontological entailment rules. Our probing results show that PLMs can memorize certain ontological knowledge and utilize implicit knowledge in reasoning. How- ever, both the memorizing and reasoning per- formances are less than perfect, indicating in- complete knowledge and understanding.

title: Quantized Side Tuning: Fast and Memory-Efficient Tuning of Quantized Large Language Models
abstract: Finetuning large language models (LLMs) has been empirically effective on a variety of downstream tasks. Existing approaches to finetuning an LLM either focus on parameter-efficient finetuning, which only updates a small number of trainable parameters, or attempt to reduce the memory footprint during the training phase of the finetuning. Typically, the memory footprint during finetuning stems from three contributors: model weights, optimizer states, and intermediate activations. However, existing works still require considerable memory, and none can simultaneously mitigate the memory footprint of all three sources. In this paper, we present quantized side tuing (QST), which enables memory-efficient and fast finetuning of LLMs by operating through a dual-stage process. First, QST quantizes an LLM’s model weights into 4-bit to reduce the memory footprint of the LLM’s original weights. Second, QST introduces a side network separated from the LLM, which utilizes the hidden states of the LLM to make task-specific predictions. Using a separate side network avoids performing back-propagation through the LLM, thus reducing the memory requirement of the intermediate activations. Finally, QST leverages several low-rank adaptors and gradient-free downsample modules to significantly reduce the trainable parameters, so as to save the memory footprint of the optimizer states. Experiments show that QST can reduce the total memory footprint by up to 2.3× and speed up the finetuning process by up to 3\times while achieving competent performance compared with the state-of-the-art. When it comes to full finetuning, QST can reduce the total memory footprint up to 7\times.

जाता है। This guide aims to provide a comprehensive overview of quantization, including its history, applications, and implementation techniques. इतिहासThe concept of quantumization was first introduced in the 1960s by John von Neumann, who proposed a method for reducing the complexity of digital computers. तब से, परिमाणीकरण का उपयोग विभिन्न क्षेत्रों में किया जा रहा है और यह मशीन लर्निंग अनुप्रयोगों में मशीन सीखने के लिए उपयोग किया गया है जैसे कि��Introduction to Quantizingसंख्यात्मक डेटा का परिमापकण एक संख्यात्मक मूल्य को एक सीमित संख्या में परिवर्तित करने की प्रक्रिया है जो एक निश्चित सीमा के भीतर रहता है जिसे परिसीमा कहा जाता था। In machineलर्नंग, क्वांटाइजेशन का उद्देश्य डेटा को अधिक कुशलता से संग्रहीत करना और संसाधित करना है जबकि इसकी सटीकता बनाए रखना है(Kohan et. al., 008). क्वैंटाइजिंग का एक सामान्य उदाहरण छवि डेटा में रंग चैनलों को 8 बिट तक कम करना होगा। The process ofअधिकतम सीमा तक सीमित करने के बाद, प्रत्येक रंग चैनल को दो बिट्स में कूटबद्ध किया जाएगा। १஦ बिटों में प्रत्येक चैनल के मूल्य के आधार पर, एक बिटमैप बनाया जाएगा, जो छवि का प्रतिनिधित्व करता है । Quantizating can also be used to compress audio and text data. तदनुसार, पाठ डेटा की मात्रा को सीमित करके, हम पाठ को संग्रहित करने, संप्रेषित करने या विश्लेषण करने से जुड़ी कम्प्युटेशनल लागत को काफी कम करते हैं। Similarly, quantizing audio data can reduce its size and improve the quality of the audio. title: Semantic Sensitivities and Inconsistent Predictions: Measuring the Fragility of NLI Models
abstract: Recent studies of the emergent capabilities of transformer-based Natural Language Understanding (NLU) models have indicated that they have an understanding of lexical and compositional semantics. We provide evidence that suggests these claims should be taken with a grain of salt: we find that state-of-the-art Natural Language Inference (NLI) models are sensitive towards minor semantics preserving surface-form variations, which lead to sizable inconsistent model decisions during inference. Notably, this behaviour differs from valid and in-depth comprehension of compositional semantics, however does neither emerge when evaluating model accuracy on standard benchmarks nor when probing for syntactic, monotonic, and logically robust reasoning. We propose a novel framework to measure the extent of semantic sensitivity. To this end, we evaluate NLI models on adversarially generated examples containing minor semantics-preserving surface-form input noise. This is achieved using conditional text generation, with the explicit condition that the NLI model predicts the relationship between the original and adversarial inputs as a symmetric equivalence entailment. We systematically study the effects of the phenomenon across NLI models for \text{\emph{in-}} and \text{\emph{out-of-}} domain settings. Our experiments show that semantic sensitivity causes performance degradations of 12.92% and 23.71% average over \text{\emph{in-}} and \text{\emph{out-of-}} domain settings, respectively. We further perform ablation studies, analysing this phenomenon across models, datasets, and variations in inference and show that semantic sensitivity can lead to major inconsistency within model predictions.

title: Entity Tracking in Language Models
abstract: Keeping track of how states of entities change as a text or dialog unfolds is a key prerequisite to discourse understanding. Yet, there have been few systematic investigations into the ability of large language models (LLMs) to track discourse entities. In this work, we present a task probing to what extent a language model can infer the final state of an entity given an English description of the initial state and a series of state-changing operations. We use this task to first investigate whether Flan-T5, GPT-3 and GPT-3.5 can track the state of entities, and find that only GPT-3.5 models, which have been pretrained on large amounts of code, exhibit this ability. We then investigate whether smaller models pretrained primarily on text can learn to track entities, through finetuning T5 on several training/evaluation splits. While performance degrades for more complex splits, we find that even when evaluated on a different set of entities from training or longer operation sequences, a finetuned model can perform non-trivial entity tracking. Taken together, these results suggest that language models can learn to track entities but pretraining on text corpora alone does not make this capacity surface.

title: EconAgent: Large Language Model-Empowered Agents for Simulating Macroeconomic Activities
abstract: The advent of artificial intelligence has led to a growing emphasis on data-driven modeling in macroeconomics, with agent-based modeling (ABM) emerging as a prominent bottom-up simulation paradigm. In ABM, agents (*e.g.*, households, firms) interact within a macroeconomic environment, collectively generating market dynamics. Existing agent modeling typically employs predetermined rules or learning-based neural networks for decision-making. However, customizing each agent presents significant challenges, complicating the modeling of agent heterogeneity. Additionally, the influence of multi-period market dynamics and multifaceted macroeconomic factors are often overlooked in decision-making processes.In this work, we introduce **EconAgent**, a large language model-empowered agent with human-like characteristics for macroeconomic simulation. We first construct a simulation environment that incorporates various market dynamics driven by agents’ decisions regarding work and consumption. Through the perception module, we create heterogeneous agents with distinct decision-making mechanisms. Furthermore, we model the impact of macroeconomic trends using a memory module, which allows agents to reflect on past individual experiences and market dynamics.Simulation experiments show that EconAgent can make realistic decisions, leading to more reasonable macroeconomic phenomena compared to existing rule-based or learning-based agents. Our codes are released at https://github.com/tsinghua-fib-lab/ACL24-EconAgent.

title: Don’t Blame the Annotator: Bias Already Starts in the Annotation Instructions
abstract: In recent years, progress in NLU has been driven by benchmarks. These benchmarks are typically collected by crowdsourcing, where annotators write examples based on annotation instructions crafted by dataset creators. In this work, we hypothesize that annotators pick up on patterns in the crowdsourcing instructions, which bias them to write many similar examples that are then over-represented in the collected data. We study this form of bias, termed instruction bias, in 14 recent NLU benchmarks, showing that instruction examples often exhibit concrete patterns, which are propagated by crowdworkers to the collected data. This extends previous work (Geva et al., 2019) and raises a new concern of whether we are modeling the dataset creator’s instructions, rather than the task. Through a series of experiments, we show that, indeed, instruction bias can lead to overestimation of model performance, and that models struggle to generalize beyond biases originating in the crowdsourcing instructions. We further analyze the influence of instruction bias in terms of pattern frequency and model size, and derive concrete recommendations for creating future NLU benchmarks.
